description: From Middle English future, futur, from Old French futur, from Latin futūrus, irregular future active participle of sum (“I am”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰuH- (“to become, be”). Cognate with Old English bēo (“I become, I will be, I am”). More at be. Displaced native Old English tōweard and Middle English afterhede (“future”, literally “afterhood”) in the given sense.

entries.meaning: Having to do with or occurring in the future.
examples: Future generations will either laugh or cry at our stupidity.

entries.meaning: The time ahead; those moments yet to be experienced.
Something that will happen in moments yet to come.
Goodness in what is yet to come. Something to look forward to.
examples: There is no future in dwelling on the past.

entries.meaning: The likely prospects for or fate of someone or something in time to come.
(grammar) Verb tense used to talk about events that will happen in the future; future tense.
(computing, programming) An object that retrieves the value of a promise.
